text: We'll hear arguments next in 71-839, Erlenbaugh against the United States.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
I think we will let you do that right after lunch.
Oh!
Mr. Grubb you may continue.
Thank you, Your Honor.
Mr. Grubb?
Yes sir.
Do I understand that that's the opinion you are just been reading from is in a case not referred to in either one of the briefs?
No --
Okay now the citation --
Yes.
Thank you.
Now in McCormick the Seventh Circuit --
Well the boundary of the case of the gambling house near the state line is one out of this Court last term where the term before, isn't it?
Rewis.
Yes.
Yes Rewis, I am going to go --
That is in 401 US, the reference that you told --
Yes it is in 401 that is right, I did not have the U.S. Citation I have the Supreme Court citation, the Supreme Court Reporter and LED.
What's that (Inaudible)
Yes Rewis it is a -- I have the Supreme Court Reporter citation here.

I suppose it is reasonably assumed isn't it Mr. Grubb that Congress was well aware that there were highly specialized newspapers as you kept your eyes this bulletin that catered particularly to people who were betting and to organized gambling, isn't that, accurate?
That is right.
What do you have to say about it?

That is right and I think that these -- Section 1953, be the latest in the statute should control, I believe does control that the two seconds must be construed impaired material and I cited the what I think is a leading case on that and I believe that altered them Section 1952 to the extent it was not to be -- that it was a exempt for use.
Mr. Tuttle.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the court.
Mr. Tuttle, I don't suppose this is really bears on the statute, but is that all the kind of information a scratch sheet contains, is just what horses have been scratched?
Oh!
But the reason it's called the scratch sheet is because it has the scratch information?
That's right, but that's only one aspect of the information which is contained.
Mr. Tuttle assume I don't know anything about it, doesn't also include the morning line?

That would be called the morning line, the handicapper's odds and the other information that I have spoken and the rapidity with which this is distributed or must be distributed is reflected in the facts of this case.
Are you emphasizing that he paid for them?
As a matter of fact, they are, Your Honor.

If this material which is in this sheet, racing sheet that you have got was a special column on the sports page of a conventional newspaper and was transported in the ordinary course of sending thousands of them to Philadelphia or Richmond or somewhere else.
Oh!
So it has to be connected that with some other activity?
Well, again it depends -- the act requires that it be shipped with a given purpose to promote an unlawful activity and requires also that act of the shipment is used to promote the unlawful activity.

Well, if these are the same gentleman have, then purchase to 'x' a hundred of them and sent them by a special courier and delivered them to people in furtherance of this, then that would violate this statute in your --
No question about it, in our view, assuming of course, that they were then used in furtherance of the unlawful activity.
Thank you, Mr. Tuttle.
I have no further, Your Honor.
